column1: Primary lymphoma of the brain is cancer of white blood cells that starts in the brain.
Patients who have a weakened immune system are at high risk of primary lymphoma of the brain.
Common causes of a weakened immune system include HIV and having had an organ transplant (especially heart transplant).
Primary lymphoma of the brain may be linked to Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV), especially in people with HIV.
Primary brain lymphoma is more common in people ages 45 to 70.

Symptoms of primary brain lymphoma may include any of the following: - Changes in speech - Changes in vision - Confusion - Fever - Hallucinations - Headaches - Leaning to one side when walking - Loss of coordination - Numbness to hot, cold, and pain - Personality changes - Seizures - Weakness in hands - Weight loss
The following tests may be done to help diagnose a primary lymphoma of the brain: - Biopsy of the brain - Head CT scan or MRI - Spinal tap (lumbar puncture)
Primary lymphoma of the brain is usually first treated with corticosteroids to control swelling and improve symptoms.
The main treatment is with chemotherapy.
Younger patients may receive high-dose chemotherapy, followed by an autologous stem cell transplant.
Radiation therapy of the whole brain may be done after chemotherapy.
Without treatment, patients with primary brain lymphoma survive for less than 2 months.
Patients who are treated with chemotherapy often survive 3 to 4 years or more.
